description: Triangle Measure. Relationships between angles and sides.

slides.title: What is Trigonometry?
slides.content:
# Triangles üìê

Deals with relationships between side lengths and angles of triangles.
Essential for:
- Navigation (GPS)
- Construction
- Physics (Waves)

slides.title: The Unit Circle
slides.content:
# Circle of Radius 1 ‚≠ï

Extends trig beyond 90 degrees.
- X-coordinate = $\cos(\theta)$
- Y-coordinate = $\sin(\theta)$
- Radius hypotenuse = 1

slides.title: Radians vs Degrees
slides.content:
# Slices of Pi ü•ß

- **Degrees**: 360 in circle.
- **Radians**: $2\pi$ in circle.

$180^\circ = \pi$ radians.
Math formulas (Calculus) work much better with radians.

slides.title: Pythagorean Identity
slides.content:
# The Big One üîë

$$\sin^2 \theta + \cos^2 \theta = 1$$

Ideally derived from the Unit Circle ($x^2 + y^2 = 1$).
Allows converting between sin and cos.

slides.title: Graphs of Sin and Cos
slides.content:
# Waves „Ä∞Ô∏è

Periodic functions.
- **Amplitude**: Height from center.
- **Period**: Length of one cycle ($2\pi$).
- **Phase Shift**: Horizontal shift.
Sound and Light are modeled with these waves.

slides.title: Inverse Trig Functions
slides.content:
# Going Backwards üîô

If $\sin(30^\circ) = 0.5$, then:
$\arcsin(0.5) = 30^\circ$ (or $\sin^{-1}$).

Used to find the Angle if you know the Sides.

slides.title: Law of Sines
slides.content:
# Non-Right Triangles 1 üìê

For any triangle ABC:
$$\frac{a}{\sin A} = \frac{b}{\sin B} = \frac{c}{\sin C}$$

Use when you know pairs of opposite angles/sides.

slides.title: Law of Cosines
slides.content:
# Non-Right Triangles 2 üìê

$$c^2 = a^2 + b^2 - 2ab \cos C$$

Generalization of Pythagoras.
Use when you know 3 sides (SSS) or Side-Angle-Side (SAS).

slides.title: Double Angle Formulas
slides.content:
# Doubling Up ‚úñÔ∏è

$\sin(2\theta) = 2 \sin \theta \cos \theta$
$\cos(2\theta) = \cos^2 \theta - \sin^2 \theta$

Useful for simplifying complex expressions.

slides.title: Applications: Navigation
slides.content:
# Bearing üß≠

Use trig to calculate position from heading and distance.
If you walk 10km NE, how far North are you?
$10 \times \cos(45^\circ)$.

slides.title: Applications: Physics
slides.content:
# Forces üèóÔ∏è

Resolving vectors into X and Y components.
- $F_x = F \cos \theta$
- $F_y = F \sin \theta$

Sliding down a ramp, tension in wires.

slides.title: Polar Coordinates
slides.content:
# Circular Grid üéØ

Instead of $(x, y)$, use $(r, \theta)$.
- $r$: Distance from center.
- $\theta$: Angle.

$x = r \cos \theta, y = r \sin \theta$.
Great for spirals and circular motion.

slides.title: Analytic Trigonometry
slides.content:
# Proofs üõ°Ô∏è

Proving one side equals the other using identities.
Like a puzzle game to simplify equations.

slides.title: Oscilliation
slides.content:
# Springs and Pendulums üï∞Ô∏è

Simple Harmonic Motion.
$x(t) = A \cos(\omega t + \phi)$

Trig models anything that vibrates or swings.

slides.title: Trig Summary
slides.content:
# Recap üìù

- **SOH CAH TOA** for right triangles.
- **Unit Circle** for all angles.
- **Waves** describe sound and light.
- Laws of Sines/Cosines solve any triangle.
